title: 111_hr230
content: The Act titled "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009" allows for affordable refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009 authorizes Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing and new mortgages on single-family housing. Lenders must meet requirements set by the Director to have their mortgages considered for purchase. The Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009 allows Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to purchase qualified refinancing and new mortgages on single-family housing. Lenders must meet requirements to have their mortgages considered for purchase. Qualified mortgages must meet specific criteria and can be either refinancing or new mortgages on one to four-family dwellings. The term "qualified refinancing mortgage" refers to a mortgage on a one to four-family dwelling that is the mortgagor's principal residence and is used to pay off an existing first mortgage originated before January 1, 2008. The qualified refinancing mortgage must be used to pay off a first mortgage on the same property originated before January 1, 2008. The new mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually, a term of 30-40 years, and meet underwriting standards set by the Director. Prepayment penalties are waived. The qualified new mortgage must meet underwriting standards set by the Director and have prepayment penalties waived. The principal loan amount must be used to purchase the property subject to the mortgage. Under the Act, new mortgages must meet underwriting standards and have prepayment penalties waived. The principal loan amount must be used for property purchase. Enterprises can establish exceptions to underwriting standards for refinancing and new mortgages. Enterprises must set aside qualified mortgages for securitization. Under the Act, new mortgages must meet underwriting standards and have prepayment penalties waived. Enterprises can establish exceptions to underwriting standards for refinancing and new mortgages. Each enterprise must set aside qualified mortgages for securitization, issuing and selling securities based on them with approval from the Secretary of the Treasury. Securities can be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates, with maturities and interest rates determined by the enterprise with the Secretary's approval. Securities issued by an enterprise under this subsection are considered exempt securities. Securities issued by an enterprise under this subsection are considered exempt securities and are not guaranteed by the United States. Mortgages set aside must be adequate for timely payments on the securities. Each security issued must clearly state it is not a debt or obligation of the United States. The Federal Reserve will establish a credit facility for enterprises to access credit at rates similar to Treasury securities. The requirement for enterprises to purchase mortgages will end after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines the Director as the head of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, the Enterprise as the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and the Secretary as the Secretary of the Treasury.
